name: 2,6-dinitrobenzonitrile
Reason: The basic structure is benzene which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The addition of the nitrile (C#N) group tends to increase the melting point through strong dipole-dipole attraction and possible linear interaction with other molecules, we can estimate this increase to be around +80°C. Each nitro (NO2) group is highly electron-withdrawing and introduces more intermolecular attraction through dipole-dipole interactions, not to mention the possible formation of hydrogen bonds with other molecules, so we can add approximately +40°C per nitro group. There are two nitro groups, which implies an accumulative increase of around 80°C above the contribution of the nitrile group. Therefore, adding all these contributions to the base value of benzene gives us the predicted melting point.

name: 2,6-dinitrobenzonitrile
Reason: The basic structure of 2,6-dinitrobenzonitrile is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The nitrile (C#N) group increases the melting point due to strong dipole-dipole attractions and possible cyano stacking interactions, contributing an estimated increase of about +80°C. Each nitro (NO2) group is an electron-withdrawing group that can significantly increase the melting point due to its ability to participate in intermolecular attractions such as dipole-dipole interactions and potential hydrogen bonding. We can estimate each nitro group to contribute an increase of about +30°C. With two nitro groups, the total increase would be approximately +60°C. Combining these effects gives us an overall prediction for the melting point.
